body:
> You can change the method to return the try and then throw the exception in the controller's main.

`ExecManifest.initialize` is called by both: controller and invoker. would you suggest we impl in both of them ?

Open to your suggestion, but before making the change I want to make sure we're ok to duplicate the code.

> There's no point to using a try if this method is going to throw an exception.

 I also thought of that but I changed my mind seeing we have 3 operations to `Try`: `parse`, `flatMap`, and `map`, and the intent is to throw an exception only on error.

Let me know what you think.

The operation that will throw is the json parse; hence removing the try and documenting that the method will throw is all the same. I slightly prefer the return of a Try so it's explicitly known through the types this method can fail and the caller should address failure; yes you'd have to throw in both controller/invoker main but really it would be achieved by just doing a .get in the result for example hence not much duplication at all. But it's fine to just throw here and document it. You will need to adjust some tests iirc.

>  I slightly prefer the return of a Try so it's explicitly known through the types this method can fail and the caller should address failure

ðŸ‘ thanks @rabbah . I'll make the changes to be more explicit.

@bjustin-ibm @rabbah can one of you pls merge?

i hadn't realized that the proposed solution was to force a GC on exit from every node invocation. this will penalize everyone, for the perhaps rare case of nodejs actions that manipulate large Buffers?

also, use of `Promise.all` means that if, for some reason, `global.gc()` fails, then the activation will fail. is this what was intended?

Two cents
1. We no longer have node 0.12, we are going to upgrade to node 6.10.2. Will the new v8 in 6.10.2 have something new we can revisit this problem to solve in other ways
2. Can this be an opt in? instead by default penalize every single invocation on the critical path?

@rabbah @starpit

yes, I think it's possible to perform the check only at some point, i.e. every second invocation, or if the memory is above X, or only when reused the first time, ... 

my initial thought was to avoid any logic to reduce the probability of intermittent failures, therefore we discussed between (1) do it always (2) just expose and let the user run it. 

Current implementation is (1), but I would be ok to use (2) and let users who have issues (I know one by name) to try it out and see if it helps.

Would you feel better if we choose (2). we could switch to (1) anytime later once we get good indications from users that this feature is helpful at all?

what do you think?
for now, i would just expose gc to the actions, and document that those using large Buffers may need to use explicit gc.
i just realized that #1980 does not enumerate the memory and log min/max system settings.
Yes; this is still open :) 1980 made the general facility available.
close issue to test Slack webhook

> for now, i would just expose gc to the actions, and document that those using large Buffers may need to use explicit gc.

I agree with this.

However, for completeness: Another problem with the current implementation (using `Promise.all`) does not guarantee _when_ the GC will actually run - perhaps before, during, or after the action code runs. Additionally, there is no reason to wait for GC to complete successfully (as @starpit  also points out) before returning the result.

_If_ we believe that GC should run automatically, I think it should be queued up to run after the result has been returned, as implemented here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/compare/master...bjustin-ibm:node_gc#diff-4ca0b607ab76fb60662c0e52545ee30bR114  In this way, the action run is not penalized to also include the automatic GC.

do we set `--max-old-space-size` based on the action's limit? this might be tricky, in the face of updates to an action's limit (which would require restarting the container in order to use the updated max-old-space-size).

but, it could be that node would do the right thing, if we set the heap size to be the container's memory limit. the v8 source seems to indicate that the default max old space size is fixed.

also, c.f. https://github.com/cloudfoundry/nodejs-buildpack/pull/82
if you update the limits, you get a new container.

> if you update the limits, you get a new container.

yes, that makes sense. 

so: the default initial old space size is 1.6GB. the original tests didn't even get to that point, in terms of Buffer allocation. So the v8 VM probably feels no urgency to run a GC. i wonder if this is a general problem.

yeah. this fails, even with in-heap objects:
```
% wsk action update big big.js -m 128
% wsk action invoke big -p mb 10 -br
{
    "length": 10485760
}
% wsk action invoke big -p mb 10 -br
{
    "error": "The action did not produce a valid response and exited unexpectedly."
}
```

where big is
```
const main = params => ({ length: new Array(params.mb * 1024 * 1024).fill(0).length })
```

it seems important to match the heap size to the container limit. i have no idea why v8 isn't doing this for us.

To be reliable, we would have to be more conservative and set old space to be memory limit less young space, large space, and node size itself.  Probably even more.   An alternative is to allow a little bit of slack by using `--memory-swap` to create a tiny bit of elasticity.  We don't want much swapping but occasional use of it for an infrequent major GC is not terrible.  This also has other use cases such as when there are binaries/images that are large but are actually unused.   A possible choice could be something like `--memory=512m --memory-swap=640m`.   Of course, this should be done in conjunction with the heap parameter adjustments.

@dubeejw - was this the desired behavior?  this additional output comes from invoking the action invoke cli command method under the covers.  calling the lower level action invoke method would avoid displaying the action invocation output.

@rabbah I'm done with the changes based on your review. I've also added a unit test with an invalid `runtimes.manifest` value.

I think what you're pointing out is that there are health dependends on the invokers (and kafka), but also on the db and the new health protocol for the invokers creates a phase ordering problem and cannot deal with cascading failures. I agree we should make this more robust and systematic.

A related issue is that if the db is not properly initialized, for example, views are not installed, the controller will report a service unavailable error. It detects this on demand - rather than proactively.

@rabbah thank you very much for the suggestions. I've applied them all.
Only a small diff on `else` (I personally try to live without it to save indentations, and make the code easier to follow).

TLDR; Let only the user change the active state of the rule, system should not be changing it when being updated.

I would argue that it's useful for staging or swapping deploying if a user wants to use rules that a rule's active state remains unchange when it's being updated.

@ddragosd Thanks.
I also hope many people can develop ow with docker for mac.

The main Issues being handled in this pr are as follow.

1. Docker0 network does not exist on OSX. (No direct connection to container is possible)
2. Squid proxy returns `503 service unavailable` in case of connection failure(`connection refused`)
3. Because of 2, few tests are failing.

If you use docker-compose with docker for mac, surely you will face similar issues.
And same workaround will work for you.

Last time, I tried to solve 2 by changing the semantic of core modules.
But many people had concerns on it.
Now I am trying to change the behavior of proxy.


And regarding question on squid, I am using squid as a forward proxy.
In OW world, nginx is being used as a reverse proxy.

While proceeding this issue, I focused on minimizing manual user work and changes on existing module as much as possible.

Nginx also can be used as a forward proxy.
But we need many configuration changes on nginx.
(Even I am not sure nginx can work as forward and reverse proxy at the same time)

With squid, user can just `docker pull`/`docker run` it from public docker hub.
I have no preference on squid. I just used it because it is a mature solution.

I have tested few other forward proxies such as polipo, but did not work.
Even I was thinking of implementing simple new proxy by myself and publicize it on docker hub.
Since it requires too much efforts, I am looking for the other way.

> Ok I thought the test would fail since whisk config reads from consul. I'm surprised it passed. Do you know why?

Yes, b/c the consul properties are not set when the test runs, `WhiskConfig` doesn't read them from consul ( https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/common/scala/src/main/scala/whisk/core/WhiskConfig.scala#L167 )
Will merge as soon as Travis completes.

Here is the first draft of design. I don't have much experience with creating actions in other runtimes than nodejs so adding only nodejs for now. Will add other runtimes as I finish experimenting with them. Any feedback will be highly appreciated.

# Using the init action

The `/whisk.system/init` action offers a convenient way to deploy an action with its dependencies to OpenWhisk.

The action accepts following parameters:

Parameters 

Parameters    | Description
------------- | -------------
name | Name of the action to be created
location  | Directory containing action files
kind  | Action runtime for example: nodejs:default, swift:default

## Creating action with nodejs runtime

To create an action in nodejs runtime, you must have `index.js` and `package.js` for any dependencies. `/whisk.system/init` installs dependencies locally using `npm install` followed by zipping up the action and its dependencies and creates an action using that zip file.

```
ls -1 helloworld/src/
index.js
package.json
cd helloworld/src/
npm install
zip -rq action.zip *
wsk action create helloworld --kind nodejs:6 action.zip
```

All you have to run is:

```
wsk action invoke /whisk.system/init --param name helloworld --param location helloworld/src --param kind nodejs --blocking
```

### Question: 

Should `/whisk.system/init` be responsible for cleaning up after creating helloworld action?

Perhaps we should not call the action "init" as this has meaning in the context of the CLI.  Perhaps we should (as most actions should) name it according to its granular function.

Also, this would be better as an "implicit" action (not explicit) where we would possible do this as part of create perhaps?
Got it - because you're writing the property file directly you suppress the consul path. Thanks for clarifying.

This issue was due to the mismatch in the /openwhisk/ansible/group_vars/all file and the code. 'all' file was latest and code was old. after reverting back to the old 'all' file. deployment went through
This issue was because the required databases were not created in the couchdb. once the Db were created fine with initdb and wipedb yml. This issue did not occur.
PG4/290 approved

Observations regarding Docker volumes from Kafka container:

- The `Dockerfile` for Kafka creates two unnamed volumes: https://hub.docker.com/r/ches/kafka/~/dockerfile/
- `docker rm` won't remove volumes unless option `-v` is specified: https://docs.docker.com/v1.12/engine/reference/commandline/rm/
- The `clean`script of Ansible `kafka` role only asserts that the `kafka` Docker container is absent: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/roles/kafka/tasks/clean.yml
- The Ansible `docker_container` module support volume management via parameter `keep_volumes` which is set to `true` by default: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/docker_container_module.html. 

In other words: at least for the `kafka` container, we don't clean up volumes when removing containers but retain them such that disk space fills up if volumes are not removed otherwise.

This PR fixes said problem. Looks good to me.

Taking this idea further, is there a way to enable users to toggle tracing on/off for individual actions?  I guess we could also allow the users to set a custom logging host and port. 

Should we also propagate the trace id to the action using an environment variable so they can pass it along to other service calls?

Moreover these will need to be parametrized per deployment so that they are proportional to the invoker/controller ratio and the operational requirements of the platform (sustained throughout, recovery time, disk availability, etc.)
@jasonpet update doc here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/docs/reference.md#javascript-runtime-environments

@jthomas Currently Tracing results will be consumed by Sys Admins and developers interested in System performance.  Here are my thoughts on extending it to action developers. 
1) Either the same Tracing server(used by OpenWhisk) is shared with users. 
    - Which would then raise question about how to control access to it.
    - Will viewing overall system trace along with action, is it relevant for the action developers?

2) Different Trace server which action developers setup
    - Propagating TraceId will only make sense if its same server, if users set their own Trace collector then trace span propagation would not work. 
    - In this case action can have code to send trace to their respective server. Host and Port info and how its toggled can be controlled with action params, so it can still happen independently of this change.
